routing_summary.excerpt_summary: Section 3 states that the former background material on IPv6 relevant to DHCPv6 has been removed from this revision and directs readers to RFC 8415 for that background, keeping the section only for numbering alignment.

Temporal.explanation: no ordering, timers, or state sequencing are involved.

ActorDirectionality.explanation: no roles, send/receive behavior, or ownership semantics are discussed.

Scope.explanation: the text clearly limits itself to non-normative background and simply points to another document.

Causal.explanation: referring to RFC 8415 as background does not affect protocol behavior or interoperability.

Quantitative.explanation: no numeric ranges, sizes, or counts are present.

Deontic.explanation: no normative (MUST/SHOULD/MAY) requirements are in this section.

Structural.explanation: no ABNF, diagrams, or formal structures to compare; the content is purely explanatory.

CrossRFC.explanation: although it references RFC 8415, doing so as a historical/background reference from a document that obsoletes it is a common and acceptable pattern, not an obvious bug.

Terminology.explanation: no definitions or terminology changes appear here.

Boundary.explanation: no edge-case or exceptional behavior is described.

candidate_issues.short_label: Use of RFC 8415 solely as historical background reference
candidate_issues.sketch_for_experts: Section 3 only says that background material has been removed and directs readers to RFC 8415 for that background, maintaining section numbering. Referencing an obsoleted document for non-normative historical/background text is normal practice in RFCs and does not alter protocol behavior or requirements. I see no inconsistency or underspecification here that would merit errata.
